senses.de: The amount of money taken by a business in a particular period.
senses.ex: Our company had an annual turnover of 1.5 million dollars last year.

Tips.title: Business Metrics
Tips.description: Turnover can measure success; higher turnover implies more sales and potentially more profit.
Tips.example: Our bakery's turnover increased by 20% this quarter.

Tips.title: Time Frame Specific
Tips.description: Turnover relates to a specific period like monthly, quarterly, or yearly.

Tips.title: Context Sensitive
Tips.description: In conversations about finance, turnover implies business revenue.
Tips.example: The new product line boosted our turnover significantly.

senses.de: The rate at which employees leave a workforce and are replaced.
senses.ex: The employee turnover in the industry is quite high.

Tips.title: Workforce Stability
Tips.description: High turnover in a company often suggests job instability or dissatisfaction.
Tips.example: Our department is addressing the high turnover issue.

Tips.title: Management Challenge
Tips.description: Turnover is a key challenge for HR to ensure a stable workforce.
Tips.example: Managing turnover is essential for a healthy workplace.

Tips.title: Cost Implication
Tips.description: Frequent employee turnover can lead to higher training and recruiting costs.
Tips.example: We need to reduce turnover to cut down on hiring costs.

senses.de: A kind of pastry with a filling folded into it.
senses.ex: I had a delicious apple turnover for dessert.

Tips.title: Sweet or Savory
Tips.description: Turnovers can be sweet, like with fruit, or savory, like with meat or cheese.
Tips.example: I prefer savory turnovers with spinach and feta.

Tips.title: Portable Snack
Tips.description: Turnovers are convenient to eat with your hands, no utensils needed.
Tips.example: Turnovers are perfect for picnics because they're easy to pack and carry.

senses.de: An act of turning something over, for example in sports.
senses.ex: The team's numerous turnovers cost them the game.

Tips.title: Sporting Mistake
Tips.description: In sports, a turnover is often seen as a mistake, losing possession to the opponent.
Tips.example: The quarterback's turnover led to a touchdown for the other team.

Tips.title: Game Dynamics
Tips.description: Turnovers can change the momentum of a game, for better or worse.
Tips.example: Our team's defense caused a turnover and turned the game around.

Earnings.wordDefinition:
Earnings refer to the profit or income that is generated after deducting expenses. It represents the amount of money a company or individual has made in a specific period of time.

Earnings are the amount of money left over after expenses, while turnover is the total amount of money earned before deducting any expenses.

Earnings are applicable in measuring profitability, while turnover is useful in evaluating the total amount of business or sales.

Exchange.wordDefinition:
Exchange refers to the act of giving something in return for something else. This is often used when discussing currency or other goods that are traded.

For example, when you exchange money for a different currency or exchange a product at a store for a different one, that is considered an exchange.

Exchange is about trading one thing for another, while turnover is about how much business a company does.

Income.wordDefinition:
Income refers to the money that an individual or business earns from sources such as salaries, profits, interests, and dividends.

Income is what is left over after expenses are deducted, while turnover is the total amount of money a business generates.

Companies use both terms to measure their financial performance, but they are not interchangeable. Income is more applicable to individuals, while turnover is more relevant to companies.

Revenue.wordDefinition:
Revenue and turnover both refer to the amount of money a business earns, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Revenue usually refers to the total amount of money a business earns before any expenses are deducted. So if a business brings in $100,000 in revenue, but their expenses total $50,000, then their net profit would be $50,000.

Revenue is a broader term that can refer to any money earned by a business, while turnover specifically refers to the amount earned from sales.

Sale.wordDefinition:
Sale refers to the number of goods or services that a company sells to customers. It is the total amount of money earned from the selling of those goods or services.

Turnover refers to the total amount of money earned by a company from all its sales in a given period, typically a year.

It includes all the sales that a company makes during that period, regardless of whether the goods or services have been paid for or not.

Sale is applicable at the individual level, referring to the selling of a single item, while turnover is applicable at the company level, referring to the total amount of money earned by a company from all its sales.

Transaction.wordDefinition:
A transaction is a one-time exchange of goods or services for money. For example, when you buy a hamburger at a fast food restaurant, you are making a transaction.

Turnover refers to the total amount of money or goods that a company earns or produces over a period of time. This can include multiple transactions, along with other sources of income or revenue.

A transaction is a single exchange of goods or services for money, while turnover is the total amount of money or goods earned or produced by a company over a period of time.

quotes.Text: The rationale for tenure is still valid. But the system has turned the academy into one of the most conservative and costly institutions in the country. Yes, conservative: Economists joke that their discipline advances one funeral at a time, but many fields must wait for wholesale generational turnover before new approaches take hold.
quotes.Title: American Economist
quotes.Name: Francis Fukuyama

quotes.Text: Football is one of those games that definitely relates to life in a lot of ways. Everything can be going good, and just like that, you have a turnover. Things are going south, you're going the opposite direction. How are you going to recover from it? That's the beauty in this game.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Torrey Smith

quotes.Text: When you play professionally, you get accustomed to turnover. Players come and go - they get injured, they get transferred, they get cut from the team. Coaches are hired, and coaches are fired. It's just part of the world you live in.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Tim Howard

quotes.Text: Employers who recognize the importance of investing in their workforce have a more productive workforce, a more efficient workforce, a more loyal workforce, less turnover, and, in the private sector, more profitable.
quotes.Title: American Lawyer
quotes.Name: Valerie Jarrett

quotes.Text: Sometimes I get caught in just trying to get assists, trying to help my teammates get a good shot, and I think I put myself in positions where I get turnovers or I force the issue.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Jeff Green

quotes.Text: The industry's much quicker. The turnover with models - I cannot keep up. And in my day, we had so much personality. We probably caused a lot more trouble, but it was fun.

quotes.Name: Carolyn Murphy

quotes.Text: Companies are recognizing that paid leave reduces training and turnover costs, that it's a formula for recruiting and retaining good workers.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Tom Perez

quotes.Text: I want to improve my shooting, my free throw shooting, keeping my turnovers down.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Rajon Rondo

quotes.Text: I think I'm pretty good at pressuring the ball, forcing turnovers.
quotes.Title: American Basketball Player
quotes.Name: Michael Carter-Williams
